section-block.rac_essential-question: What stories do we like to tell?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Book: Goldilocks and the Three Bears

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Valeri Gorbachev
section-block.rac_book_summary: The classic fairy tale about a young troublemaker is perfect for comparing sizes and capacities. There is also opportunity to study patterns.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s CReATE | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Gather three different-sized pencils and ask children to order them by height. Point out that although the pencils are all the same kind of object, they are different sizes.
Discuss fairy tales: A fairy tale is an old story with magic or talking animals that teaches a lesson. Have children name all of their favorite tales as fast as they can.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we will read Goldilocks and the Three Bears as retold by Valeri Gorbachev. Does anyone already know the story of Goldilocks? What happens?
Lala loves all types of books, especially loves reading stories called fairy tales.
Think about this question as I read and we’ll talk about it after we finish the book:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one thing Goldilocks does in the story?

section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: As you read, ask children to raise their hands when they hear a size word.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The mother bear is middle-sized. That’s another way to say medium! How can you tell that she is medium in size? Let’s compare her to the other bears.
Goldilocks went into the bears’ house! She is much shorter than the doorway in this picture. Do you think Goldilocks is shorter or taller than the mother bear?
How do you think Goldilocks felt when she went inside? (MB)
Goldilocks found porridge! It smells delicious. What do you think the porridge smells like?
Whose bed is Goldilocks sleeping in? Is this bed the shortest bed or the longest bed in the house? Why would the baby bear have the shortest bed?
There are a lot of bowls on this page! Which bowl is biggest? Which bowl is medium-sized? How can you tell?
Let’s talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What is one thing Goldilocks does in the story?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their responses.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Goldilocks goes into the bears’ house.
Goldilocks sleeps in the baby bear’s bed.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences comparing objects from the story such as bowls, chairs, and beds as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does Goldilocks eat in the story?
Could this story really happen? Why or why not?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children have varied experiences with fairy tales. Classic fairy tales such as Cinderella are told differently in different cultures. And of course, every culture has its own traditional stories! Invite children to describe and even retell the tales they name, as best as they can. Encourage them to act out or draw their favorite scenes in centers.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Another Perspective

rac_body-text.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Everyone has different thoughts and different feelings. Sometimes, someone might feel and think differently than we do about the same thing. When we try to understand other people’s feelings, we take a different perspective. Understanding how other people feel helps us be a better friend and a better person!

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread Goldilocks and the Three Bears as retold by Valeri Gorbachev. We will practice thinking about and understanding the characters’ feelings.
Clifford always tries to understand the characters’ feelings in the books he reads. That way, he can better understand why they do the things they do.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Patterns: As you read, draw children’s attention to the ABAB patterns of stripes in many of the pictures. Encourage children to say the patterns aloud with you.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: I see a pattern on the mother bear’s bag! The stripes are blue, white, blue, white. The last stripe is white. What color would be next?
Goldilocks is peeking into the window. She doesn’t know what is inside. This house is unfamiliar to her.
What do you think Goldilocks is thinking as she looks in the window? (MB)
The bears’ food is familiar to Goldilocks. She already knows how she likes to eat porridge!
I notice that the bears are outside the window in this picture. They don’t see Goldilocks! How do you think the bears are feeling? (MB)
Goldilocks decided that the father bear’s chair was too hard. Do you think the father bear feels the same way? How could the father bear’s perspective be different about the same chair? (MB)
I see a pattern on the mother bear’s chair, too! The stripes of the chair are orange, yellow, orange, yellow. The last stripe is orange. What color would be next?
Goldilocks runs away at the end! Why do you think she ran? How do you think Goldilocks felt when she saw the bears? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Ask pairs of children to act out the scene where the baby bear finds Goldilocks. Tell them to show each character’s feelings. Allow time for pairs to act out their scene for the group.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about the characters’ feelings in the story.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Understanding that other people have different feelings and perspectives helps children see how their actions can affect others. Remind children that even if two people disagree, both perspectives can be valid. Remember, too, that perspective can affect relative size: A shirt that is too small on you may be too big for someone else. (Read et.al, 1980)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Review patterns. Choose two colors of Connecting Cubes, and model creating an ABAB pattern. Encourage children to guess what color the next cube will be.
Place hexagon and triangle Pattern Blocks in a bag. Have each child take a block. Ask children to stand in a pattern of large/small/large/small. Repeat using other patterns.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread Goldilocks and the Three Bears as retold by Valeri Gorbachev.
Lala loves this story. There are so many patterns to find and ways to compare size!
As we read today, think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do the bears do when they come home?

section.rac_body-text: As you read, point out this pattern: sizes are always listed in order from largest to smallest.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Great and big are both other words for large. How can you tell that the father bear is large?
Wee is another word for small. How can you tell that the baby bear is small?
Does Goldilocks try the largest or the smallest bowl first? Which bowl does she try last?
Goldilocks always tries the largest thing first, then the middle-sized thing, then the smallest! What bed do you think she will try last?
Which bear checks his bowl first? Which bear checks his bowl last? What do you think the bears are thinking as they check their bowls? (MB)
Does the largest or the smallest bear check his chair first? I think the pattern of largest to smallest is here, too! Which bear do you think will check his chair last?
How do you think the baby bear feels when he sees that Goldilocks broke his chair? (MB)
The bears are going upstairs to check their beds. Which bear will check his bed first? Which bear will check his bed last?
Did you listen and remember as we read today? What do the bears do when they come home?
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to share their answers.
Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about the order of bowls, chairs, and beds Goldilocks tries.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do the bears check when they come home?
What did Goldilocks do when the bears came home?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Patterns are arrangements of things that repeat in a logical way. They can be made with colors, shapes, sounds, or numbers. They can even be found in the events in a book! Patterns are important for preschoolers, because they help them to predict what will happen next. Use the patterns in Goldilocks to help children make predictions.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: Let’s Create | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Revisit the term fairy tale. Why is Goldilocks and the Three Bears a fairy tale and not real? Share with children that today they will read another tale with talking animals.
Play a game of “I Spy” using sizes: I spy something large. Encourage children to “spy” small, medium, and large objects as well. Remind children that size can be relative.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read The Voice in Rabbit’s House. It is a poster that tells a story.
Goldilocks and the Three Bears and The Voice in Rabbit’s House are both stories about animals who act like people. Let’s look for other connections between them!
What stories do we like to tell?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Telling a Tale
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Measurement: Read aloud the Teacher Text on the Big Chart, stopping to ask questions and talk about size.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Caterpillar is small! How can you tell Caterpillar’s size by looking at the picture?
What does long mean? If Rabbit saw Caterpillar, would Rabbit think Caterpillar was very long? (MB)
Caterpillar is making herself sound scary! What do you think Caterpillar is thinking? (MB)
Rabbit is going to find Leopard! Is a leopard larger or smaller than a rabbit?
Rabbit is going to find Rhinoceros!
We have a rabbit, a leopard, and a rhinoceros. Which one is largest? Which one is smallest? Which one is medium?
Both Frog and Caterpillar tell the truth! But when the other animals see them, they aren’t afraid. Why aren’t they afraid anymore? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Put on a play! Invite five children to play the roles of Caterpillar, Rabbit, Leopard, Rhinoceros, and Frog. As you reread the story, encourage each child to make themselves seem as small or large as their character, and act out their actions. Repeat until all children have had a turn to act!
Provide a writing prompt about stories that have talking animals and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children compare size all the time, often without knowing it—they discuss portions of food, compare the sizes of toys, and measure their heights against their friends’. It is important to help children develop a conscious awareness of measurement with formal words (large, small, tall, short). Point out these words in context.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S CREATE | WEEK 1: Tell a Tale

section-block.rac_body-text: Use a small cup to demonstrate capacity. Show children that the cup is empty. Then, scoop buttons or beans into the cup. Is it still empty? Scoop more. Now it’s full!
Ask a child to hold out empty hands. Put Connecting Cubes in the child’s hands one by one. Tell the child to say full! when no more can fit. Repeat so every child has a turn.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s read Goldilocks and the Three Bears one more time.
This book is a fairy tale! Who remembers if fairy tales tell us stories or give us real-life facts?
We have learned a lot about characters’ different feelings. When we read today, think about this question: If the bears invited you into their home, what would you do there?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Earlier we read that the cottage is small. But Goldilocks looks so tiny in this picture! From Goldilocks’s perspective, is the cottage small or large? (MB)
Let’s act out Goldilocks entering the bears’ very large house!
The bowls are full of porridge! But Goldilocks is eating some. Will the bowls be full once she’s eaten some of the porridge?
Let’s pretend to taste the porridge in the large bowl. It’s hot!
What happened to the baby bear’s chair? How does the baby bear feel when he finds out? (MB)
Let’s pretend to sit very carefully so that the chair doesn’t break!
The baby bear’s bowl is empty! Is there any porridge left in it?
How do you think the baby bear feels? It’s important to ask others before we take their food. Let’s pretend to ask the baby bear if we can have some porridge. (MB)
Goldilocks runs away at the end. Let’s pretend to run away quickly!
How do you think the bears feel now? What could Goldilocks have done or said to help them feel less confused? (MB)
If the bears invited you into their home, what would you do there?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Then, ask several children to share with the group.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I would ask for some porridge.
I would say goodbye when I left.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story comparing two people or creatures and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What would you ask to eat?
I would ask for some p___ (porridge).
I would ask for some porridge.
The story of Goldilocks is more than 100 years old. Why do you think it has been told for so long?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschoolers may know that a small container holds less than a large one. It will take time for them to understand that containers that are tall and thin may hold the same amount as containers that are short and wide. Encourage children to use containers of many different sizes and shapes as they play so they can explore conservation.
